title: Where can I download college textbooks from online for free? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m not sure about downloading them, but I can tell you how we did it in medical school. Some of the texts were $700 and this was 25 years ago! There was no way I could afford them. I wasn’t the only one. We had a group of 5 of us. We waited till Kinkos had a photocopying sale. It would get as low as half penny/page in Chicago sometimes. We’d take 5 books to photocopy. Each of us took 5 binders for ourselves. Then we’d each copy a book, in 5 copies. Darn copiers didn’t collate back then LOL We’d then sit there and make the piles and put a copy of each page on the 5 piles. It took a few hours of hard work, going as fast as we could turn pages. When we were done, we’d have a book for maybe less than $20. Now I know there will be people screaming. I don’t care. Those that had the money bought the books. If I HAD the money, I would have too. But I was crawling out of poverty and being thrifty was the only way. Not having the book meant certain failure. Of the 100 students on my class, we may have been the only five to do this. My anatomy partner was starving to death, literally, trying to make it through school. I was afraid he’d die before we graduated and I wasn’t doing much better. Used books weren’t an option. Everyone kept them for boards and studying for residency interviews.

Publishers invest tens of thousands of dollars in getting a manuscript ready for publication. Their employees invest their time. The authors do, too. The only way for any of them to get their investment (time and/or money) back is to have control over the right to make copies. When you pirate a copy, you steal that control — and therefore their ability to make a living from the work that you obviously value. You can get free copies from most university libraries. You can buy a print copy with a friend and trade it back and forth. You can get a scholarship that covers books. You can rent a copy. There are many options for reducing your costs without destroying the foundation of the book business, and of the creative economy, in general.
